captions.text:
Yo yo this here is Sparky Sweets
PhD and this week we gettin buck

wild with Lord of the Flies by
William Golding.

Dis book starts when a G5 full of
prissy British boys crash lands on

a remote island in da Pacific.
Among the survivors be homies

Ralph, Piggy, Jack, and Simon. In
order to get their boys in line,

Piggy and Ralph snag a big ass
shell that they can use to holler

at their boys and talk bidness.
They call this shell “the conch.”

Now all these kids appoint my boy
Ralph as the leader and lets

Jack be the head hunter. At first,
Jack be too much of a bitch to kill

for food, but soon enough dis
gangsta busts his cherry and gets
some o dat good pork.

All the while, the youngins be
actin scurred cuz some little fool

say he saw a monster, but Ralph be
all like “chill shawty, that shit’s
all in yo head”

Then one day Jack rolls up to camp,
blows the conch, and say that he

saw the beast with his own eyes and
that Ralph ain’t got the balls to

be the leader. Ralph say “Boy who
you think you talking to?.” And

Jack be like “look. If you all want
some of dat bacon, you gonna have

to leave Ralph’s posse and join my
new crew. Straight up.”

So Jack and his crew shank another
pig and impale its head on a stick

as an offerin to the beast. Then,
my brutha Simon has a vision of dat

pork talkin to him! That pig head
be referred to as “The lord of the

Flies” and it start spittin cold
truth up in Simon’s ear: He say

that the beast ain’t somethin them
boys can hunt cuz it ain’t nothin

but the violence in dem kids
hearts.

When Simon hauls ass back to camp,
all dem little homies mistake him

for the beast and waste that fool
in a cracked out frenzy. Even Ralph

and Piggy get some licks in. Wheew,
this shit gettin real.

After that whack ass dance, Jack
and his posse storm Ralph’s crib

and steal Piggy’s glasses, which be
the only thing they can use to make
a fire.

Ralph just ain’t having it with
this honkie Jack. So Ralphie boot

up and starts brawlin wit this
fool. During the tussle, Piggy gets

thrown off a cliff and the conch
shatters. Outnumbered by Jack’s

homies, Ralph books it for the
shore and just when he about to

collapse, Ralph peeps a Naval
officer chilling in the water. When

this playa sees dem kids tryin to
kill Ralph, he be like “Have you

kids lost your damn mind?” Then he
puts dem kids on the boat and takes

em back to civilization. But they
innocence is long gone.

Alright listen up play boy. dis
book be an allegorical effort to

take all the fucked up shit about
society and find its origin in

human nature. By watchin these
little white boys lose their mind,

we reminded of humanity’s capacity
for evil and how man-made moral
systems be straight up superficial.

But you wanna know the wackest
irony of all, my man? Even though

adult life may look all righteous
once dat navy playa drops in, the

truth is, that soldier boy be smack
in the middle of a war. In fact,

this fool was trying to get the
drop on his enemy when he found

these kids. So the real tragedy up
in here is that they ain’t nobody

to save civilized humanity from
they violent nature neither. You
feel me?

You also best recognize that the
central symbol up in this heezy is

that pig-head on a stick, or what
the narrator be callin “The Lord of

the Flies”-another name for
Beelzebub, the prince of demons.

AKA THE DEVIL. And like the Devil
be doin, he representing the

destruction, decay and
demoralization of man kind homie.

Yo, and if you wanna get all
Freudian up in this bitch, you can

say that The Lord of the Flies be
representin “the id,” which

functions only to ensure survival.
Laws, moral codes, even

intelligence itself don’t mean jack
shit when the id be in charge.

Look, You just ain’t rollin with
the big dawgs unless you know bout

this here motif son. All throughout this book
dey be

recurring patterns of fallin- Piggy
fallin off the cliff and the conch

falling with him, the falling
parachutist, Ralph fallin at the

navy man’s feet. All dat shit be
emphasizing the “fall of human kind."

Also, the Loss of Piggy’s sight be
a symbol for the fall of reason.

When that punk Jack boosts Piggy’s
glasses to make a fire for his

gang, it straight up indicates the
transition from the reign of reason
to the reign of savagery. Ya heard?

Yo. Thanks for watchin Thug Notes.
Catch yall next week.

comments.author: Bryant Goh

comments.text:
+Bryant Goh It's one of the three parts of the human mind in one of Freud's 
theories. There's the id which controls basic desires and has no morals 
ethics or thought for anyone. Then there's the ego which controls all of 
the good aspects of human nature like morality and selflessness, and makes 
sure we don't do things which harm others . Finally there's the superego 
the logical part of the human mind, whose main motivation is intelligent 
logical thought and an understanding of consequences.

comments.author: Dominic Graham

comments.text:
Lord of the Flies killed off the only two characters in it that I actually 
gave a shit about, with very little buildup to justify it. Simon's seizure 
disorder wasn't even foreshadowed until the title "character" shows up for 
one chapter and is never seen again. There was precisely one reason for 
their deaths, and that was to drop Anvils of Symbolism on the reader. There 
was no subtlety, no finesse about it. There's no *depth* to having your 
story swerve with screeching tires to grab that Senseless Death Out of 
Nowhere Just Because pickup it needs to get on the required reading list.

Simon and Piggy's deaths didn't impart any deep message to me. Simon's 
death was just a checkbox. He was the most sympathetic and interesting 
character in a book that I was being forced to read for class, and since 
there was no dog in this book, he was going to be sacrificed on the altar 
of cheap shock value by the end of it. Piggy's death -- while having a 
*slightly* better set-up -- doubled down on that with added grossout, but 
the most important thing was that it evoked from me the Eight Deadly Words: 
"I don't care what happens to these people."

Oh, and then Ralph gets saved by Deus ex Machina on literally the *very 
last page,* because the author had written himself into a corner and 
couldn't bear to follow through and kill the main character when all 
circumstances pointing to that ending.

Lord of the Flies is a heavy-handed pile of symbolism and bad writing 
techniques. It also makes the implicit assumption that the behavior and 
attitudes of a bunch of boys from a British boarding school are 
representative of all humanity. Its point is about as valid as the Stanford 
Prison Experiment (i.e., NOT).﻿

to them both; they are the exploitation of children becoming men by those 
who find themselves superior to both

the way that the state is idealized as not holding hands with the nation to 
where states-rights are somehow an emboldening of the people is so 
ridiculous... the rights lie with the people, as does the true 
interpretation of what their life is worth; getting past that gridlock is 
where the tire can finally hit the road and real proliferation and 
reconciliation and burden-free breathing be made

suggesting a difference between dictatorships and fascism is a 
rationalization of preference of one over the other in the resignation that 
life is the sum of those parts, eating and breathing determinism; ain't 
havin it son

comments.author: 99batran

comments.text:
+99batran  is fascism relative?  don't you have to live for something? 
 economics seems like the sort of facile motivation that jack guilt-trips 
ralph with "I got food.  Fuck your foresighted optimism."  "Your food is 
fine Jack.  It's just fine.  You gonna make us starve?  Or you gonna wait 
for hunting orders?"  I mean fascism is a military word for exploitation, 
but it's also nature's way.  People are above it, but only by as much as 
their plan b can allow them to be.  Does Jack recognize any plan b that he 
is giggling to himself is too gay, or is he too exhausted from hunting and 
feeling self-evident in his pandering to the other hungry children?

I just wonder if there isn't a better thing to call somebody who doesn't 
know he's being fascist than fascist.  Is a fascist someone who's selective 
in his teaching method (like Scientology luring people in for years before 
springing their secrets) or is it somebody that shoots before asking 
questions (puh-lice)?  Economics and politics are both inherently fascist? 
 Then so would people be.  Jack is just a bold little kid with a bunch of 
desperate little kids.  You can draw comparisons of adults to children but 
not children to adults.  It's a warning of what we're going to become, and 
a call to recognize that we have no idea what we are.

There is no all important blame game worth playing because we all just rely 
on ourselves to give ourselves the answers we're looking for.  If we found 
a culprit, it would be blame wrongly assessed (as if on a decapitated, 
rotting carcass).  We never needed a conch; that is just a magic feather. 
 If we are less contrived by our superstitions, we can prevent killing 
ourselves off one by one to be saved by some distant future usses that will 
still be embroiled in some bullshit war stemming from some cause we risk 
getting hung up on.  I would want to say that's economics, but more 
important than what to blame would be to treasure the hand reaching out to 
us in any circumstance.  Jack is just a little boy, just like all of us [no 
girls allowed on terstosterone island].

comments.text:
You missed the whole point of Piggy's death. He wasn't just "thrown off a 
cliff", he was hit by a giant rock that was pushed by the savage Roger who 
was overcome with bloodlust. Piggy represented Prometheus, a god who gave 
humans fire but then he was punished by Zeus by being chained to a rock and 
getting his liver eaten out by a vulture everyday. This idea adds on to how 
the superego, sense of morality or reason which Piggy and Prometheus 
possessed, will be destroyed and conquered by the savage human id, natural 
instinct. Just putting that out there, awesome video! :D﻿

comments.author: Joaquin Perez

comments.text:
Sparky, my man, you’ve been played! The plot is set during WW3 not WW2 
(casual mentioning of an atom bomb by Piggy at the beginning of the story, 
when atom bombs were kept secret from the public until the very end of the 
war, and the fact that a British territory or dominion was destroyed by an 
atomic bomb) and we don’t know which enemy the navy officer at the end was 
looking for (but it’s not WW2 Japanese soldiers). We don’t even know he was 
looking for an enemy. He’s by himself on the beach, and the first words out 
of his mouth are “hullo”. Hardly what you would say to your enemy as you 
storm his first lines of defense, right? But you’re correct, there is a 
much more devastating, “civilized”, atomic war going on when the officer 
chides the boys for acting like savages.
 
That said, I love your reviews, keep ’em coming! 5 minutes is really short, 
but maybe you could have pointed out that Jack and Ralph are archetypes of 
Cain and Abel. Jack only becomes violent and savage as a way of reclaiming 
the leadership which he felt Ralph “stole” from him during an impromptu 
election at the beginning of the book. The pig’s sacrifice can be seen as 
representing the blood sacrifice which led Cain to become the first 
murderer (in the Bible at least). You could almost say that Jack bears the 
physical “mark of Cain” on him (he is described as “ugly”), but that would 
be pushing it a bit far.﻿

comments.author: MayaTheKat

comments.text:
+mshara1 Well, that's all about the individuals feelings toward race. Thug 
notes is just an entertaining version of spark notes. If this individual 
(Sparky Sweets Phd.) is comfortable portraying stereotypes regarding his 
own race, you should be comfortable about laughing about it too. It's 
entertaining and educational in more ways then one. Yes, you learn the 
short version of some literary text but Sparky also gives you many things 
most people miss. He always finds symbolism, and connections in these books 
most people look over. It also is a good reminder that people are not 
always what they seem and to never underestimate anyone. If anything not 
judging people based on appearance is a life lesson that will help young 
students in the future more then most things they learn in school.
